title: Cardiac Output (Fick's Formula)
description: Calculates cardiac output, cardiac index, and stroke volume using Fick's principle. The gold standard method for measuring cardiac output based on oxygen consumption and arteriovenous oxygen difference.

parameters.name: age_years
parameters.description: Patient age in years (≥70 years uses different VO2 calculation)

parameters.name: svo2_percent
parameters.description: Mixed venous oxygen saturation as percentage

parameters.name: heart_rate_bpm
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

result.name: cardiac_measurements
result.description: Cardiac output, cardiac index, and stroke volume calculations

ranges.interpretation: Cardiac output within normal range (4.0-8.0 L/min). Adequate systemic perfusion expected.
Cardiac index within normal range (2.5-4.0 L/min/m²). Body surface area-adjusted cardiac function is adequate.
Stroke volume within normal range (60-100 mL/beat). Normal ventricular filling and contractility.

references: Ragosta M. Textbook of Clinical Hemodynamics. 1st ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

Swan HJ, Ganz W, Forrester J, Marcus H, Diamond G, Chonette D. Catheterization of the heart in man with use of a flow-directed balloon-tipped catheter. N Engl J Med. 1970 Aug 27;283(9):447-51. doi: 10.1056/NEJM197008272830902.
LaFarge CG, Miettinen OS. The estimation of oxygen consumption. Cardiovasc Res. 1970 Jan;4(1):23-30. doi: 10.1093/cvr/4.1.23.
formula: CO = VO2 / [(SaO2 - SvO2) × Hb × 13.4], where VO2 = 125 mL O2/min × BSA (or 110 mL O2/min × BSA if age ≥70), BSA = √[(Height × Weight) / 3600], CI = CO / BSA, SV = CO / HR
notes: Gold standard method for measuring cardiac output
Requires arterial and mixed venous blood gas sampling
VO2 assumed: 125 mL O2/min/m² (age <70) or 110 mL O2/min/m² (age ≥70)
Body Surface Area calculated using Mosteller formula
Normal CO: 4.0-8.0 L/min, CI: 2.5-4.0 L/min/m², SV: 60-100 mL/beat
Low CO/CI: hypovolemia, shock, severe metabolic acidosis
High CO/CI: hypoxia, early sepsis, anemia, positive inotropes
Low SV: impaired contractility, increased afterload, decreased preload
High SV: bradycardia, positive inotropes, decreased afterload
Less accurate in pulmonary hypertension or heart failure
Constant 1.34 represents oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin (mL O2/g Hb)
